translated: Stories of the past
. The snake
“Like a snake that sheds its skin,
he goes on to a new existence.
So when the body breaks up,
and the life force is cut off,
the burning one doesn’t know
the lamenting of the relatives.
That’s why I don’t weep for him,
for he has gone to his destination.”
“He didn’t come from anywhere,

analyzed: na anuññātaḥ itas gataḥ  yathāgato tathā gataḥ
translated: and he didn’t go from anywhere.🔽He came as he was, and he went as he was.
So why lament?
The burning one doesn’t know
the lamenting of the relatives.
That’s why I don’t weep for him,
for he has gone to his destination.”
“If I were to weep, I’d be thin,
but what would be the point?
For relatives, friends, and loved ones,
there would be even more distress.
The burning one doesn’t know
the lamenting of the relatives.
That’s why I don’t weep for him,
for he has gone to his destination.”
“Just like a child who cries

analyzed: gacchantam anurodati  evam sampadam eva ita
translated: after the setting moon,🔽so it is with those who grieve
for the dead.
The burning one doesn’t know
The lamenting of relatives,
Therefore I do not weep for him,
he has gone to his own destination.”
“Just as a water pot, O Brahmā,
when broken is not restored,
So it is with this attainment,
one who mourns the dead is destroyed.
Burning, he does not know
the lamenting of relatives,
Therefore I do not weep for him,

original: gato so tassa yā gatī”ti.🔽Uragapetavatthu dvādasamaṁ.🔽Uragavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: gataḥ saḥ tassa yā gatī iti  uragapetavatthu dvādasama  uraga vaggo paṭhamaḥ
translated: he has gone to his own destination.”🔽The Story of the One Who Went to the Snake Realm is the twelfth.
The first sub-chapter on snakes is finished.🔽The summary:
Field, pig, rotten,
and also back, and beyond the wall;
Five, and seven sons,
and ox, and weaver;
And so khallāṭiya, nāga,
and the twelfth, the snake.
